body:
Thanks for the reply, I didn't notice the "Revert" commit attached. It feels wrong to me that I need to keep the responsibility of checking my arguments to my mailers outside of the methods. 

If we are writing a plain old ruby method, it would be preferable to say something like this

    def foo(user)
      return false unless user.is_a?(User)
      ...

Rather than to rely on type checking that argument before each call. (This wouldn't be very DRY).

    foo(user) if user.is_a?(User)


I can do this in ruby, and in controllers, and in models, and view helpers, but not in mailers. It feels off.
If I pass in incorrect values to my mailer, even if I know they are incorrect, that mail is destined to be rendered (into an error) whether I like it or not. 

I would like a standard way to exit a mailer without generating mail. If another implementation might be considered, (such as supporting an early return) let me know and I can work on a PR. Or if we should use some other pattern, let me know and I can add it to the Mailer guide.
